sparsegl 0.3.0
  • Get started
  • Reference

    Calculate information criteria.

    estimate_risk.Rd

    This function uses the degrees of freedom to calculate various information criteria. This function uses the "known variance" version of the likelihood. Only implemented for Gaussian regression.

    estimate_risk(object, x, y, type = c("AIC", "BIC", "GCV"), approx_df = FALSE)

    Arguments

    object

    fitted object from a call to sparsegl().

    x

    matrix of predictors, of dimension \(n \times p\); each row is a vector of measurement and each column is a feature.

    y

    real-valued response variable.

    type

    one of AIC, BIC, or GCV.

    approx_df

    the df component of a sparsegl() object is an approximation (albeit a fairly accurate one) to the actual degrees-of-freedom. However, the exact value requires inverting a portion of X'X. So this may take some time.

    Value

    a vector of the same length as object$lambda.

    References

    Vaiter S, Deledalle C, Peyré G, Fadili J, Dossal C. (2012). The Degrees of Freedom of the Group Lasso for a General Design. https://arxiv.org/pdf/1212.6478.pdf.

    See also

    sparsegl() method.

    Examples

    n <- 100
p <- 20
X <- matrix(rnorm(n * p), nrow = n)
eps <- rnorm(n)
beta_star <- c(rep(5, 5), c(5, -5, 2, 0, 0), rep(-5, 5), rep(0, (p - 15)))
y <- X %*% beta_star + eps
groups <- rep(1:(p / 5), each = 5)
fit1 <- sparsegl(X, y, group = groups)
estimate_risk(fit1, X, y, type = "AIC")
#>        s0        s1        s2        s3        s4        s5        s6        s7
